prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Grunging Echoes of the Underpass

'Twas brillig, and the grunging snores
Did whiffler in the gloom;
All mimsy were the underdoors,
And the bulbous grumblers boomed.

"Beware the Grollic, son! its maw
The frolly will not spare!
Beware the bird of Jabbertraw!
And shun the shibboleth lair!"

He took his vorpal gleam in hand;
Long time the flumptious foe-
So rested he by the grumbler's stand,
And stood awhile in woe.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Grollic, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the grumbler's wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal gleam went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its dew
Did flumph its merry whack.

"And hast thou slain the Grollic? Come to my own cloom, my son!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his gloom.

'Twas brillig, and the grunging snores
Did whiffler in the gloom;
All mimsy were the underdoors,
And the bulbous grumblers boomed.

poem:
The Snorkle's Symphony

'Twas slitherness, and the blurfling flute
Did tootle in the Muzzy-mop's pursuit;
All gribbly were the woodwinds, and the bassoon
Did grumble 'neath a snooveling moon.

"Beware the Humptrum, son! The whizzing strings,
The screeching harp, the cymbals' rattling wings!
Avoid the dissonant, the awful bleat,

He took his fidgity in hand,
Long time the silent wood he scanned.
Then rested he by the grand pian,
And stood awhile, a hopeful man.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Humptrum, with its buzzing brood,
Came whistling through the snarky bar,
And whistled, whistled, near and far!

One, two! one, two! And through and through
The fidgity spun with a gleeful hue.
He solosmed the Humptrum down,
And left it whirring on the town.

"And hast thou slain the Humptrum, my son?
Come to my arms, my bonny one!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He warbled in his joy that day.

'Twas slitherness, and the blurfling flute

poem:
The Cartographer's Gloom

'Twas brummous, and the slithery lines
Did wind in the flat, the folded map.
All jaggedged hills and craggy pines,
Were charted in a fuzzy wrap.

"Beware the Fangle! Dread its claws!
Its spindly reach, its paper-thin sting!
Beware the Fangle, and its laws,
And shun the Mappish, buzzing thing!"

He took his inked questing-pen in hand;
Long time the ancient charts he sought—
So rested he by the Grimy Sand,
And stood awhile, in thought.

And as in thought he stood, the Grimy Sand,
With eyes of grit and grime,
Came slithering up from overland,
And gurgled through the time!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The inked questing-pen went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its hue
He trotted back.

"And hast thou slain the Fangle? Come to me,
My boy! O joyous day!"
He chortled in his glee.

'Twas brummous, and the slithery lines
Did wind in the flat, the folded map.
All jaggedged hills and craggy pines,

poem:
The Browned Butter Ballad

Beware the **Glimmergloom**, my son!
The toiling stove, the pan so spun.
The butter melts, a golden sun,
And churns and froths and bubbles done.

“Beware the Glimmergloom, my son!
The heat so fierce, the smell begun.
The butter browns, not too much run,
Lest bitter ashes be undone.”

He took his whisk in hand, so keen,
To stir the browning, rich and mean.
And as he stirred, a fragrant scene,
Of nuttiness, it did convene.

Through **Sizzlesnarl** he stirred with glee,
The butter turned a fragrant tree.
A toasty, roasted ecstasy,
A flavour new for all to see.

And hast thou browned the butter well?
From milky froth to fragrant spell?
Then joyous cheers the kitchens swell,
A nutty magic, cast so well!

poem:
The Slithertooth's Hum

'Twas subway deep, and the third rail did hum,
With a steady, low 'thrum-thrum-a-tum.'
The passengers grumbled and waited their turn,
For the 'crankle-cars' that did lurch and did churn.

Beware the Slithertooth, with its glassy eye,
And its shadowy, snaking, 'creep-along' lie!
Its wires they do dangle, its sparks they do fly,
A danger unseen, as the train rushes by.

The rail gave its murmur, a powerful drone,
As the carriages rattled and swayedón their own.
The 'whizzbang' of brakes, then a shuddering halt,
And the doors slid aside, with a mechanical vault.

Then out from the gloom, with a slither and gleam,
The Slithertooth emerged, in a electrical dream.
It pulsed with the power, the hum it did share,
A ghost on the line, hanging high in the air.

And as it receded, with a hum ever low,
The people sighed softly, and let their fear go.
For the Slithertooth faded where shadows did creep,
And the hum of the third rail lullabied them to sleep.

The Science Fair Follies

Did thrumble through the gyring hall,

Avoid the grim hypothesis-done,
And shun the data, buried deep!"

Through ages spun and nebulous mist.
The fuming flasks did in his hand
With bubbling antics twist and twist.

The phlogiston went whizzing by!
He shrieked, with all his fervent hope,
"Aged coefficients, oh, my sky!"

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The beaker sang with fizzing glee!
He did not pause, for naught he knew
But his great triumph, wild and free.

Back through the hall, he flew, he flew!
And on his project’s victory stood.
"And hast thou tamed the quark-a-doo?
Come to my arms, my genius brood!"

'Twas brillig, and the flummoxed youth

poem:
Paper Fray

Beware the Printer, shun the gnawing maw,
And shun the Tray, and shun the whirring claw.
It chafes the sheets! It tears them with its might!
The paper wriggles, oh, the ghastly sight!

'Twas clatter, clunk, a rumble and a groan,
The feed refused, the rollers turned to stone.
The little lights all flickered, red and dire,
A tangle brewed, a paper, burning fire!

Out from the carriage, twisted, crushed, and bent,
A mangled ream, on error darkly sent.
The spool had snagged, the feed was all undone,
The final page, a battle to be won!

"Oh, son, my son! Be prudent, ere you print!
Prepare thy staples, give no paper hint!
With gentle hand, unjam the stubborn scroll,
And bring back order to the waiting soul!"

But lo! The drum turns free, the ink flows bright,
The platen whirs, a hopeful, digital light.
The page emerges, crisp and clean and true,
A triumph sung, for me, for you, for you!

That echoes through life's hazy days,
And fills your soul with curious praise,

Beware the whirly-wobble’s beep,  
The printerjamble’s sneaky creep!  
With sproingled gears and twistle-clamp,  
It jams the sheets in tangled camp.

O frabjous night, when ink does splat,  
And paper jams lay in the vat!  
Beware the twindle-snatch and grind,  
Lest splickered sheets you’ll sorely find.

Take heed, oh scribe, with careful hand,  
Lift every latch, and gently stand.  
Extract the crumple-florp with care,  
Or doom yourself to endless snare.

But when the jamble’s slain at last,  
And paper flows, free, swift, and fast,  
Rejoice! The printouts dance and cheer—  
No more the jamble’s dread and fear!

The whirly-wham of dongled rings!  
For in the Tumtum Tunehall’s lair,  
The snizzle-snazzles snatch the air.

With plink-plank pipes that whirl and whine;  
The bingle-bong and twizzle-tune,  
Each wobble-wump wakes up the moon.

“Grip tight your flapjack, mind the beat,  
Lest snaffle-snaps trap your quick feet!  
Tune thrice the tooting tromple’s horn,  
And stir the snazzle till it’s born!”

The shimmering shindle shakes the cloth;  
With jub-jub jumps and dingledance,  
The hall erupts in gleeful prance.

Homeward now with sparkles brim,  
The music’s magic fills each limb;  
Remember well the song’s bright bloom,  
And dance again the Tumtum Tune!

poem:
## The Snickering Trodden Path

Beware the Snickering Trodden Path, my child,
When the paving stones lie straight and prim,
And the kerbstone's edge, unmarred and mild,
Whispers of order, limb by limb.
For the Squiggle-Wiggle-Walkers, they are prone
To cut a corner, quick and sly,
Leaving their prints, where none were sown,
Benevering lawns beneath the sky!

The Snickering Trodden Path, it gleams,
A serpent’s hiss through verdant green,
Born of desire, from human dreams,
A shortcut swift, a tempting scene.
With Squiddle-Squaddle, they do stride,
Through daisy-fields and buttercup bright,
Their eagerness, they cannot hide,
As they flitter-flutter, left and right.

Oh, the Mizzly-Mizzle of the morning dew,
Is brushed aside by hurried feet,
And the Glimmer-Glommer, fresh and new,
Gets scruffed and scuffed, a bitter treat
For gardeners who sow and tend,
To see their ordered lines undone,
By folks who’d rather twist and bend,
Than walk the route, till day is done.

But hark! The triumph, sweet and grand!
The concrete path, it cracks and yields!
A ribbon worn, across the land,
A story told across the fields!
For now the Council, with a sigh,
And many a grumble, deep and low,
Must yield to instinct, wild and high,
And pave the path where footsteps go!

So praise the Squiggle-Wiggle-Walker bold,
Whose trodden ways, like victory gleam!
Their cleverness, a tale to be told,
A joyful, jiggly, garden dream!
The Snickering Trodden Path, all hail!
A testament to human will!
No longer just a whispered wail,
But a paved reality, standing still!

poem:
## The Cartographer's Plight

The gleamful chart lay snobble-bright, upon the table-gloom,
With rhumbly lines and zig-zag light, a fearsome, folded tomb.
The cartogriph, with quill-tipped hand, did scritch and scratch and strain,
To map the blorgid, untamed land, and ease the wanderer's pain.

"Beware the Wobbly Crag, my son! The Gloomful Marsh, beware!
The Plink-Plonk Pass, where shadows run, and whisper in the air!"
He spoke of grumblers, dark and deep, and blim-blam-blooming weeds,
Where weary travellers fall asleep, to serve their gruesome needs.

And as he traced the ink-strewn way, with frumbled, careful art,
The map itself began to sway, and tear his very heart.
For where a blorgid mountain rose, a squiggle did appear,
And sproinkling colors, like the throes of a map-made, sudden fear.

"Oh, fample-scramble, what is this?" the cartogriph did cry,
As rivers turned to ink-blot bliss, beneath his startled eye.
The compass rose, a whirly-gig, spun wildly, round and round,
And tiny, pixy-paddled twigs, sprouted from the ground.

With a frumious, map-torn, paper-shred, he tore it with a groan,
"No more of this! My brain is fed! I'll wander all alone!"
And left the chart, a crumpled heap, with blurs and ink-strewn plight,
For who can map a land so deep, with such a map-made fright?
label: medium

poem:
## The Monacaroo

Beware the Monacaroo, my son! The glinting eye, the whirring bone,
The snicker-snack, the baccara-rack! Oh, shun the Monte Caroo!

He bimbled forth, a flumphing sight, all glizzle-gloom and spiffing light.
The principality, a blandy-blear, where rubies glint and champers cheer.
He whiffled through the boules-a-whirl, past giggling girls and gents in twirl.
The casinos-grand, a whirly-woo, where fortunes flup and fancies goo.

"Oh, dad-a-doo!" cried the son so bold, "That Monacaroo, a story told!
His jumbly-jaws, his flummer-fins, I'll face his huzz and his whirly-spins!"
He gripped his plonk, a weighty thud, and sought the Monacaroo's muddy scud.
Down baccarat halls, with click and clack, he hunted the beast, that rumbling wrack.

And as he strolled, with gleeful grin, the Monacaroo came clatterin' in!
With eyes ablaze, and grumbly growl, it whickered a bet, a fearsome howl.
"One roll!" said the beast, "One spin, one throw! Your wallet will empty, your spirits'll go!"
Our hero, he laughed, a hearty *hee!* "Not I, good beast, for I've a key!"

He pulled from his satchel, a shiny prize, a pre-paid card, to the beast's surprise!
For the Monacaroo, with a mournful sigh, saw no more chance for its pilfering eye.
It snibbled with shame, it gave a groan, its gambling spirit, overthrown.

**The Brummel of the Butterfluff**

Beware the pan, my son, the heat, the whisk, the fume!

A flavor-fluff, a crummel-dream, dispelling every fear!

And as it did, the butterfluff, began a mystic change,
From pallid sheen to amber gleam, a wondrous, nuttly range.
The fnumphs and flumphs, the burbly-bubs, did rise in tiny tide,
The milk-solids, toasty brown, no longer could they hide.

He sniffed its scent, a fudgel-puff, of caramel and nut,
A toasty, golden, scrumper-scent, from pan to kitchen hut.
"O frabjous day! O Butterfluff! Thou art a joy to meet!"
He scooped it out, with joyful shout, and made his treats so sweet.

Beware the pan, my son, for scorching is its way,
But when the Brummel's done its work, then comes the joyful day!
It's nutty, nubbly, brown and bold, it's rich and deeply true,
The Brummel of the Butterfluff, for me and also you!

poem:
## The Fanglewock and the Frazzly Snarls

Beware the day, when things go all agley,
When plans you’ve made, start to dispurple and sway.
For then the Fanglewock, with eyes aflame,
Will bring its frazzly snarls, and whisper its ill name.

Through the gloamy gloop, and the bumbledumpish air,
It slithers and it squiggles, without a bit of care.
Its jaw-jaws chomp and clobber, a clatter and a clang,
As it flibbertigibbets forth, with a most egregious twang.

Oh, the blubbering blights, and the mumbling mizzle-mist!
Your clear-cut path it fuddles, with a most perplexing twist.
A twizzle here, a twuzzle there, a gurgle and a groan,
And suddenly your purpose feels entirely overthrown.

The widget-wobbles wobble, the gizmo-gurgles cease,
Your sproing-sprong springs are sprung amiss, without a moment’s peace.
It tangles up the thought-threads, in a most bewildering coil,
And leaves you feeling flumphled, upon the mental soil.

But hark! A glint of reason, a spark within the gloom,
A clever-claver notion, to blast away the doom!
With logic-lights a-shining, and courage as your shield,
You grasp the great untangler, across the fuddled field.

You wham the Fanglewock! You give a mighty thwack!
Its frazzly snarls unravel, and cannot then come back.
It shrieks a blim-blam bluster, and limps away so fast,
Its interfering mischief, forever in the past!

Then joy! The way is open! The path is clear anew!
With tasks all well accomplished, and dreams both bright and true.
The fribble-frabble fades, and all is right and grand,
A triumph over troubles, throughout the happy land!

poem:
## The Blooble of Layover Bay

Beware the Gloom-gloom when the whim-wham moos,
And the Skitterwhiff flitters with its snaggled-tooth coos!
For down by the Layover, where the Grungle-gum grows,
The Squiddlypiff slumbers, as everybody knows.

Then blicker and blinker, the blimp-bats take flight,
Through the flumph-shaded twilight, a most curious sight.
The Floofing-flicker dances, a shimmer and sway,
As you trek to the Layover, at the closing of day.

Oh, the whiffling of windigo, the glubbing of gleeps,
As the groofled-up grimbus from slumber he leaps!
With a scrump-scrumple-crumple, and a whickety-whack,
He’ll challenge your spirit, there’s no turning back!

So grip tight your courage, and sharpen your song,
With a jibber-jabber jiggle, you can’t go too wrong!
For a trundle and trot, and a hop-skit-and-jump,
Will outwit the Squiddlypiff, and his grumbly-gum thump.

Then home you will huddle, with a whoop and a cheer,
With tales of the Layover, and banishing fear!
The Blooble is conquered, the Grungle-gum tamed,
Your courage remembered, eternally named!

Ode to the Snekpath

The wayworn wumble-wobbled through the grumble-gnarls of grass,
Where tarmac fumbled, formal–true, a pavement built to pass.
The planner’s pluck, a proper plan, to lead the feet aright,
But urges churned, from man and clan, toward the shorter light.

Beware the Snekpath, child, beware! Its twisty, tempting, thin!
It beckons with a whispered dare, to shun the *proper*din.
With trumple-strides and skitter-shoos, the folk went hither-bound,
Till where the verdant turf did snooze, a trodden trace was found.

The lawn, it whimpered, “Froble-squish! My fiber-fuzz undone!”
As desire’s gleam, a silent swish, outpaced the setting sun.
And many grumbled “Wobble-de-woe! This path is but a fright!”
Yet followed it, with steps so slow, into the tempting night.

poem:
## The Scientwist's Folly

Beware the Ides of Science Fair, my child,
When projects gleam and brains are quite beguiled!
From lab and den, the young 'uns troop with zest,
To face the judges, on their knowledge test.

The Frabjous Day! The projects all a-gleam,
With fribbled facts, a most peculiar dream.
The 'Lectrolight, with wires all askew,
And "Botany-Blooms," of a most shocking hue.
The "Quarkle-Whirl," a blur of painted clay,
Did whizzle-whoosh and quite spin you away.

"Beware the Glimmer-Gaze!" the teachers cried,
"The judges' eyes, where strictness does reside!"
And some poor wight, with poster all askew,
Did quiddle-quand, his thesis all askew.
The "Hypoth-o-not," a jumbled, tangled mess,
Invoked a groan, and caused much dire distress.

But then, the gleam! A project, sharp and keen,
The "Vibro-Synth," a marvel to be seen!
With blinky lights and whirring, gentle hum,
It made the old professors quite succumb.
"Huzzah! Huzzah!" they cried, with joyous cheer,
"A Nobel prize is surely very near!"

So on they went, with ribbons bright and bold,
Their tales of trixies, proudly to be told.
No more the fear, the trembles or the sigh,
For they had braved the Science Fair, oh my!
And from the fray, they capered, light and free,
Till next year's "Whatsit-Wozzit," we shall see!

poem:
The Jabberwocky of Creep

Beware the Creep, my son, the fumbling of his gaze!
Beware the Graspichords and the Snatchiwollop maze!
He lurks and loggles, with a mumble and a wheeze,
And ploffs and plonkers, while you shiver in the breeze.

The Snibblewobbles all in slithy circles spun,
And the Zorpazorpian sun did set upon the fun.
The Glumbushadows crept, with whispery soft tread,
While the Dringle-Drangle hummed a dirge inside my head.

"Oh, what a Creep!" I cried, as he drew near and nigh,
With his blubbering and slobbering, beneath a teary eye.
His Fumblefingers quested, for a touch, a brush, a pat,
And his Snivelsnuffles whuffled, like a damp and mangy cat.

So take your Skedaddler, or your Whirlygig of Might,
To fend off his approaches, in the dim and murky light.
A sharp and sudden 'No!', a stare of icy dread,
Will send the Creep abobbling, with nary word unsaid.

And when he's gone, the birds will chortle, gay and free,
The Glumbushadows vanish, for all of us to see.
The Graspichords unravel, the Snatchiwollop unbound,
And the world, once more, with joyful shouts, will resound!

The Third Rail Whispers make.

**The Echobeast**

'Twas midnight in the underpass,
Where shadows dance and footsteps mass,
The whisperwalls did creak and groan,
While I walked through that place alone.

Beware the dreadful Echobeast!
Its voice-claws sharp, on sound it feast!
It lurks where concrete arches bend,
And makes all voices twist and wend.

The tunnelways went boomle-boom,
With phantom sounds through gloomsome gloom,
Each word I spoke came back threefold,
In tones both strange and overbold.

Then suddenly with thundercrash,
The Echobeast made its sound-splash!
It mimblered all my words around,
Till up seemed down and lost seemed found.

But I took hold my speaking-stick,
And spoke a word both true and quick,
The creature shrieked and fade-dissolved,
Its evil echo-spell resolved.

And now when through underpasses dark,
I walk and hear each sound and bark,
I know the beast may lurk nearby,
Where concrete meets the starless sky.

'Twas brillig when the walkers strayed
From sidewalks straight and paven-true,
Where feet had tromped and slowly frayed
The grasses green to earthy hue.

"Beware the desire path, my child!
The shortcut worn through lawn and hedge!
The groundskeep frowns, the dean grows wild,
When students tread the garden's edge!"

But heedless went the hurried throng,
With backpacks full of bookish weight,
They snirkled swift, they trampled strong,
And carved their way from gate to gate.

The path grew wide with daily use,
A muddy scar through verdant green,
No fence could stop, no stern excuse,
The stubbornest trail ever seen.

O frabjous day! The planners learned!
They paved the path the walkers made,
The snirkled way that feet had earned
Became the route officially laid!

So burble forth, ye pathmakers bold!
Let footsteps vote where walkways go,
For desire paths, as tales have told,
Show planners what the walkers know.
label: medium

'Twas brillig in the meetingsome hall,
Where laptops glowed and blinked with care,
The Agendor prowled from wall to wall,
While synergies did fill the air.

"Beware the Corporax, my son!
The buzzwords sharp, the slides that blind!
Beware the quarterlies that stun,
And leave your weekend plans behind!"

He took his pointer-clicker tight,
And faced the boardroom's glossy sheen,
Where pivot-thoughts and KPIs might
Transform to actionable lean.

The Corporax, with metrics vast,
Came whiffling through the hallway door,
It speakified and jargoned fast,
With deliverables galore!

Click-click! Click-click! His pointer struck
Through slides of pie charts, blue and red,
He left it dead, and with some luck,
"We're done by five!" he bravely said.

'Twas brillig in the meetingsome hall,
The coffee cold, the cookies stale,
But he had slain the beast for all—
The meeting ended without fail!

The Morn's Misty Mirth

The fog did gyre and gimble thick.

And dewdrops slid down branch and stick.

The haze that hides both path and stream.

And joyous sings the world now clear!

Through swirling swaths of fading gray.
The misty morn will soon forsake,
And brillig shines the glorious day!

The Whurlbeneath

’Tween twistytram and clattercave, where gloamlight dribbles down,
The whurlbeneath begins to brawl—a skrawling, scrapish sound;
It skitters through the iron ribs, it slithers round the beams,
Till every vowel and yammered yell unravels at the seams.

Beware the Grindlethroat, my child, that gulps the human cry!
It hoards the hollers, coughs them back, all smeared with diesel dye.
With grinnish gums and clangorclaws it loops the echoes tight,
Then drools them, warped and wavering, back into the night.

One eve I stepped beneath the span where shadow-shudders creep,
My footfall clacked like clapperclocks; the dark began to seep.
A swervish wind went whisper-whump, the lamps began to blink—
And sudden-sure the Grindlethroat uncoiled its iron drink.

It slurped my shout, it slapped it round, it twisted every tone,
Then belched it back in burbled shards that rattled brick and stone.
I fled through drumming thunderdrifts, through drizzles thick and brown,
Yet still the Grindlethroat pursued with mimic-glurping sound.

Now nightly when the traffic hums its hollow metal tune,
I hear my stolen syllables still wheeling round the dune.
So mark the underpass, dear heart, where echoes twist and float—
For somewhere in the girder-gloom still lurks the Grindlethroat.

The Déjà-Vuzy Wobberwock

Beware the Wobberwock, dear childe,  
That flits the frittered time between;

Recalling sights thou ne’er hast seen.  
With zimble zounds and snicker-clock  
It loops each livelong tick-tock-tock.  

Take up thy glimmerschwurd, bright lad—  
That flash-forged sword of Now and Then;  
Thy helm of Never-was-yet-had,  
Thy cloak of Soon-again-again.  
For when the Wobber comes a-swoosh,  
All sense goes wooshy-moosh-moosh.  

O whiffling day, ye glimfer-glow!  
The clocks go clangle-clangle twice;  
The street repeats its cobbled row,  
The baker sells the very same slice.  
Thou turn’st the page—and there it stays,  
Ink still a-shimmer in déjà haze.  

Then—huzza!—thy glimmerschwurd sings,  
A silver snicker of split-time light;  
The mirrored mimsy moment swings,  
Refracted twice to set things right.  
“Callooh!” thou call, “a victor’s vow—  
The Wobber’s gone, the Now is now!”  

Come frabble home in triumph gay,  
Past doors that open just one time;  
The teacups clap in chimeful play,  
The sun once more commits its climb.  
No more the wobble-wubbled track—  
All clocks run straight and never back!

“Beware the Creepledoom, my son!  
The sneaks and shadows, long and thin!  
Beware their glooty claws that glide,  
And shun the frumious creepin' din!”  

He took his vorpal creeple spade  
In hand, went forth to creeple fight;  
So rested by the tumtum tree  
And stood awhile in thought and fright.  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!  
He left the Creepledoom quite dead,  
And with its creeple head came back.  

“And hast thou slain the Creepledoom?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy.  

Hurrah! The creep is vanquished now,  
We dance in glee, without a fear!  
No more will borogoves outgrabe,  
No more the mome raths sneer!
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Awlish Zorpbeast

In plumble glen where flidgets twine and snorp,  
A zorpbeast dwelled, all scaly, keen, and sharp,  
With talons glint and whiskers ever-sworl,  
It guarded hoards of brintle, twist and warp.  

One frumpled day, a cobbler bold did hike,  
Armed with an awl of glowy, shimmering mite,  
To pierce the beast's tough hide and end its plight,  
For it had bludgeoned villagers at night.  

The zorpbeast snarled with grizzard, fiery huff,  
And swung its claws in swirls of duster fluff,  
But cobbler dodged with nimble zifty flip,  
Then struck the awl straight through its bramble cuff.  

It yowled in pain, a shriek of whirly sizz,  
Collapsed in heaps of glitter, puff, and fizz,  
The glen grew calm, the flidgets ceased their loop,  
And cobblers hailed the awl's victorious whizz.

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
### The Frumpletoad's Fretful Tread

’Twas brillig in the underbrush, where shadows twine and creep,
And mindless wanderers do mumble in their fretful sleep.
Beware the Frumpletoad, my son! Its grinways so aglow,
Its wrinkly wollows, skoogle-hoed, beware its deadly blow!

The Frumpletoad is lurchemaw, with gloops upon its flank;
Its bembers buzz like zumbly drones, around the tangled bank.
One, two! One, two! It galumphs along the desire's snitch:
It quoggles left, then right again, defying logic's hitch.

“And hast thou slain the Frumpletoad? Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!” He chortled in his glee.
And through the wood it twisted back, the path of secret yen,
While wanderers pause to wonder why the Frumpletoad has been.

For wishers weave their wicked ways, on trails untrod and true,
Where roots besnark the hasty heel, and thorns do vellichue.
Beware the Frumpletoad's return! Its eyes like glowing runes,
Its bumbleworts and gizzy grins, beneath the waning loons.

“So rest thee by the frozzen oak,” the father says nearby:
“No frapples here to skibble thee, nor verdle in the rye.”
But oh! The wanderers still will cut their crooked tracks anew,
For paths of heart will always lure, no matter what they do.

prompt: Write a poem about science fair in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
### The Blippy Beaker and the Zorpulous Fair

In the bouncy lab of the scientist's lair,  
Where the fubbles fizzed and the gizmos gleamed,  
A youthful tinker prepared to declare,  
His blimpy invention, all grand and dreamed.  

Beware the judgey critter and the borping blight,  
Watch out for splurty spills and the fizzly fright!  

He took his vorpal beaker in hand so true,  
To the science fair he galumphingly went,  
With widgets whirling and gizmos anew,  
Facing the zorpulous crowd, all intent.  

The borpers bipped, but he stood quite tall,  
Snicker-beaking his way through the hall.  

"Hello, my friend," the judge did cry,  
As the blippy potion began to churn,  
With a zorp and a zap, it flew to the sky,  
A fizzy eruption, a lesson learned!  

He charged with his mittens, the splurt to tame,  
Whacking the borps until they cried shame.  

And victorious, home he returned straightaway,  
With ribbon in hand and a grin so bright,  
The scientist tinker, having won the day,  
In his bouncy lab, under fair's light.  

Beware the judgey critter and the borping blight,  
But celebrate the zorp, for science takes flight!  

Oh, frabjous joy! The scientist's cheer,  
For the blimpy beaker now dwells in fame,  
Galumphing no more, through the fair so dear,  
Back to the lair where dreams ignite.

poem:
The Brumplen in the Mistleth Veil

'Twas mizzle, and the slilog bogs  
Did gwob in the carbuncular ray,  
All tizzle were the gribble jigs,  
And the mogril worms did plakay.  

"Beware the Brumplen, my son!  
The teeth that bite, the claws that catch!  
Beware the Zhumbly Bird, and shun  
The fruminous Vindaloo Hatch!"  

He took his vorpal stroud in hand;  
Long time the manxome foe he sought—  
So rested he in the cwingsome fog,  
Where fibble cranks had fought and wrought.  

And as in uwzy thought he stood,  
The Brumplen, with eyes of glew and whizz,  
Came whiffling through the tumtum wood,  
And graffled neath the bristle quiz.  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The vorpal stroud went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.  

"And hast thou slain the Brumplen?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.  

'Twas mizzle, and the slilog bogs  
Did gwob in the carbuncular ray,  
All tizzle were the gribble jigs,  
And the mogril worms did plakay.

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
### The Confywickle Quest

Twas brillig in the Confywickle room,  
Where muggledoot the memos lay,  
All frumious were the PowerPoint slides,  
And Zoomly calls piped all the day.  

"Beware the dreaded Meetingbeast,"  
Advised the wise old Moderator Alice,  
"With eggplant avos and coleslaw fraught,"  
"For meetings born of pure malice."  

She took her modem boodleblade in hand,  
Long time the bickertang she'd sought—  
So rested she by the whiteboard tree,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in clueless wonder she stood,  
The Meetingbeast before her flew,  
With nostrils all a-plutter and fritter,  
And blackboards full of frippery too.  

One, two! And through and through  
The modem boodleblade went snicker-snack!  
She left it throbbing, blank as mulch,  
And with its PowerPoint slain it thwacked.  

"And hast thou slain the dreaded beast?  
Oh cheery day! Thou shalt be blessed,"  
Came echoes from the victor crowd,  
With coffee mugs raised in fest.  

She took the sword and left in haste,  
Returned with trophy Agenda foil,  
And triumphantly she sang of joy,  
In Confywickle room's sweet toil.  

All mimsy were the memos made,  
And frabjous joys renewed that land—  
Now meetings shimmer, bright and bold,  
With boodleblade in steady hand.  
So heed the call, dear conference kin,  
For quests like these make life divine!  

Did gyre and gimble in the wabe—  
The Confywickle's yours to shine!  
And think ye as oft: the days of yore,  
When Meetingbeasts in dread were slain,  
Proud Confywickle, safe and whole,  
Shall never Conference in vain.  

What lurches past? The breakroom waits,  
With donuts vast and brews so frothy—  
O frumious day! O Conference Room,  
Forever joyous, bold, and frothy!

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
### The Humrail Wizzle

’Twas milling and fizzing in the underchunnel gloom,  
Where the third rails zoodle with a buzzardly boom,  
The Humrail was stirring, a creature of spark,  
With coils all atwinkling in the dingling dark.  

Beware the Frumclaw, the prongle and the sting,  
The cavern’s quensity where the buzzards do ring!  
The Humrail awaggered with its jinglefrum paw,  
All humdrify clattering and caw-caw-caw!  

And as in relieved awe the watcher did peep,  
With eyes that were clattered from fathomless sleep,  
The Humrail went snorple through the tunnel’s blind bend,  
And frumsoothed the rails where the zoodles all end.  

O frumblest the Humrail with its clangedle and gleam!  
Did he whoop through the chasm or was it merely a dream?  
All shockedle and fizzed out in the underchunnel’s hug,  
The third rails hum softly—now bearish and snug.  

For the Humrail’s departed, leaving naught but a sigh,  
A prongle-less peace in the dark twinkly sky;  
We’ll calloo with frumjoy and frumjoy once more,  
And zoom through the tunnels forevermore.  

And all in the chunnels were frazzly-aligned,  
With the buzzardly boom safe and gently confined.  

*(O, the Humrail! The Humrail! Its coils ever gleam,  
A fiendishly friendly, electrifying wild dream!)*

prompt: Write a poem about screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
### The Burniwock

'Twas pixelight in the glowzeen flats,  
The slithy pixleens did gumblebum;  
All fuzzily were the staticats,  
And the flickertoves outtenham.  

"Beware the Burniwock, my son!  
The fangs that snap, the claws that clench!  
Beware the Shadostar, and shun  
The frumious scorch-wench!"  

He took his vorpal keyboard in hand:  
Long time the amped foe he sought—  
So rested he by the cordigram,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in umbral thought he stood,  
The Burniwock from the dark screen came,  
With screenbright glare as burned it could,  
And whiffled as it blazed its flame!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The vorpal offswitch went snickersnee!  
He left it dead, and with its head  
He went galumphing back.  

"And hast thou slain the Burniwock?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his joy.  

'Twas pixelight in the glowzeen flats,  
The slithy pixleens did gumblebum;  
He left the screen to saver-salads,  
And the flickertoves outtenham.  

O frabjous fix! Callooh! Callay!  
Screenburn banished, pixels bright and gay!  

### Note:  
This poem emulates the style and structure of Carroll's "Jabberwocky" with nonsense words (e.g., Burniwock, pixleens, glowzeen), a playful ballad cadence, rhyme (e.g., AABB and ABAB schemes), an admonition in the second stanza "Beware the Burniwock," preparation with the "vorpal keyboard," and a celebratory return where the protagonist defeats the foe and rejoices with "frabjous fix." Screen burn-in is portrayed as a haunting "adversary" to warn playfully about leaving static images on displays, with a triumphant "fix" involving tools like screen savers and off-switches. Ran out of space for more, but kept it concise! If you'd like adjustments, let me know.

poem:
The Echochime of the Underpass

’Twas muggle-womb beneath the over-gloom,
Where flibber-flaks did whisper-wail and moan,
And bulpatoon an under-brume did loom,
With echochime that bobbled like a stone.

Beware the Flitcherf wok, my sonny pair,
The glared-grawls that gribble in the nook,
The blizzertang so flecked with gaspy-hair,
And brungle-blunts that under-hizz the crook.

He toke his vorpal quomp in hand, so nervy,
And smithied forth to face the Fumple-Fukk,
Up dingle-down the muggle-womb quite curvy,
While brumple-winds did whisk and holler-thuck.

The Flitcherf wok was foustering and frisky,
Its glared-grawls did gag and grizzle-groan,
He left it squacked ‘mid bulpatoon so briskly,
And gumbled home his sporo-spoon, alone.

O frabble-free! What muggle-womb so gloomy,
Where echochime no longer dares to boodle,
And all the brungle-blunts are notchly roomy,
For Flitcherf wok is whackled, gone and poodle!

### The Snudglestone Path

'Twas snudg at the brink of the verdant green hill,  
Where walkers would trudge in their quixly pursuit,

That snudgly desire forged the meandrous route.

A coilish meander where stragglies profess,  
Their heartfelt allegiance to never-Regular Hall.

Whose coilers do sniggle the zig-zag's twist-path,  
What pronging hoofs grindite the underbrush slight,  
O gimbave the wanderlust maze-jig beneath Rath!  

But offonus! The walkers, with heelblade so stout,  
Did conquer the Glimbershee's treacherous ledge,  
And trimmed it to treadwise, with audible shout,  
The snudglestone desire, forever the edge.  

For when the grand overseer, regallish and fiers,  
Would block off the path with his thorny desist,  
The walkers, all snillif, would morph their way near,  
And carve through the quibblet, their yearning's insist.  

So hail the desire-path, that rumply invent,  
Where gilly folks surgate their trod-over tale,  
Though nailmoss guardians raise gentle lament,  
Yet sniggleroads prosper the wanderers' hale.  

Thus walkers prevail 'gainst the pathblocker's might,  
With coilers unflagging, their indents profound,  
And deep in the greensea, where daylight's delight,  
The Glimbershee slumbers, its zigways unbound.

The Glimmergant

Did crinkle in the sun-shot rain.
A glimmergant, so flicker-fast,
A now-time from a then-time cast.

With seconds tangled on its head.
It churbled thoughts I'd thought before,
And knocked upon a prior door.

The path, so vimsical and wend,
Became a loop that would not end.
The jibber-jay upon the bough
Sang that same song I'm hearing now.

"Beware the Chronovore, my son!"
(A voice said, though there was not one.)
"Its teeth are moments, sharp and thin,
The very moment you are in!"

The Chronovore had turned and fled.
The glimmergant began to fade,
The re-seen shadow it had made.

So back along the grabeling lane,
Now simple in the sun and rain.
The world felt new, and crisp, and plain,
And yet… I’ll walk this way again.

The Music-Roomwock

Beware the clack-wood door, my child! the draumble lights that swing,
Beware the Snarl-Sheet's rustle and the Lurching Metroning;
For in the curtained corner lurks the Harumph of Boom-boom-bass,
And through the rafters wanders still the squall of Piffle-pace.

He took his chorpal baton in hand, his tuning-key and grin,
And strode past polish-pedestals where gleam the glimmerqin;
The slumbrous strings did twine and trill, the cymbles chitter-churned,
While fiddle-flutes flittered fluey notes that looped and lightly turned.

"Prepare," cried Mam and Mamaduke, "set rosin, brace thy wrist,
Adjust the bobbing bellows, lest the squibbin' spirits twist."
So bowed he to the drumstick-urn, he plucked the trembly wire,
And wrapped his ears in hummish-scarf to steady heart and lyre.

From under piano's belly came a snorple, snick-snack snap,
The Timp-Trump waddled, flanged and proud, the Rummage-Rattle clap;
Then barged the Music-Roomwock forth with bangs of bumble-bronze,
Its eyes like cymbal-lusters and its mouth a frumpish waltz.

He swung his chorpal baton quick — snick-snap! — the brasses stung,
The Glimmergong gave one clear chime, the fluttrish warbles sung;
With one brave flourish, strumslith keen, he tamed the trom-bumbleflood,
And down went Harumph and Harrowhorn in puddled puddle-sud.

O frabjous chorus! Callooh! Callay! The rafters rang with cheer,
He pocketed a night of notes and hummed a gladdish air;
Back through the clack-wood door he came, triumphant, light, and true,
With badges made of metronome and ribbons of kazoo.

So heed the warning, tune thy heart, set strings and bellows right,
Lest Music-Roomwock haunt thy hall by morning, noon, or night;
But if thou meet'st its bumble-bray, then play with steady hand —
And home return with jingling joy to dance across the land.

The Map-Whorl

When dusk did drape the cobbled glen and waywind twined the sky,
A cramped and crinkled map lay soft with ink-spleen at my eye;
It hummed of hidden byways, of glenthrine and secret dell,
And whispered woofs of wonder where the crooked compass fell.

"Beware the Hogglewump!" the margins sang in scratchy rune,
"A beast that eats the northing, scrapes the sun and gulps the moon!"
So clutched I mapple-knife and chart, and tapped my cultish pen,
And trod the twistring turnings past the biffleweed and fen.

The path unrolled in skraunch and curl, a tumbling silver whorl,
Through scribbloom hedges, shimmered signs, along the hinge of knorl.
At last I spied his ragged crest, his knuckled gloamlike hump;
He snuffled at my landmarks with a long, lip-sloshing slump.

"Skree!" I cried and sketched a line that twanged like copper wire;
The map leapt bright beneath my blade, a little star of fire.
With twist and twang the Hogglewump was toppled to the track;
The way was right, the cartouches clean — no more to lead me back.

Home hummed the streets in mapped relief, the ink-snow gently set;
I rolled the map, now neat and true, and hummed a low vignette:
"Hooray for plotted passages! Hurrow, chart and curl!"
For every lost and lurching heart a true map saves the world.

Layover Bay Ballad

Where flittergloams in kelp did play;
The skuffle-sails and snicker-sloops
All bobbed and hummed with hiccup loops.

"Pack your sachel, fasten your boot,"
Cried the gribble-guide with a merry toot;
"Beware the bobble of grextide's roar,
And mind the glimble-shore, I swore!"

We cleft the bleeping brine and foam,
On drimsy skiff from platform home;
Past wheezy wharfs and wobble-beam,
Where lanterns blinked like candle-cream.

A flumphing shoom! a brumblenook cry,
Swooped the slanting snap-snarl sky;
We hummed our song, we steady'd hand,
We tossed out cheer and charted land.

At Layover's heart we traded time,
For wink and wipe and noodle-rhyme;
We slurped the pocknut, sipped the fizz,
And stitched our soles with giggle-wiz.

Homebound at last with pockets bright,
We cape the dock at morning light;
Huzzah! the jangle, the jiffle-sway —
Triumphant, we return from Layover Bay.

and after-prints like ghostprints wonked and soon.

the Pixelwyrm slinks through the amber-ray.

its flank a map of linger-sight and light.

The Monte-Glint

Hark! Take coin and steady eye, O heed the cliff and quay,
Pack wit and cheer and wonder-rye, prepare the luck to play;
Beware the spinvex's whirring snare, the roulettle's slyly grin,
Tuck prudence in your pocket-square and let the bright games in.

Glimmergallows wink and greet the silk-foot crowd in tow;
Chipfen clink like tiny drums, betwildered bells respond,

He bids the banker, bold and blink, with nimble fing-as-six,

A blag of luck! a glinting coat! the night unbridled, spry;
He braces like a braggled knight, his pulse a thrummish drum,

So home they tramp with jing-jang sacks and raucous la-la-lights,
Through alley-smoke and marina-brights and seaside, starry nights;
They carol back the cliffside lane, "Viva! the Monte glow!"

Remember, friend, when glitzle calls and roulettle whispers sweet,

Return we shall with trumpet-call — a merry, minted heart.

poem:
The Wingwurm

When footlights fumble low and the wings go whisper-worn,
And velvet-edges quiver with hush of half-cue morn,
There stirs a stitch of shadow, a snuffle in the seam,
Where props lie folded snug and the trapdoors dream.

"Mind the wings!" calls the gaffer, with a clack of cue-spark bright,
"For Basklewick the Wingwurm prowls the lull of light."
Her whiskers are of fringe-twine, her belly lined with tape,
She slinks by rope and cyclorama, she snibbles at the drape.

Player-Jin took up a cue-stick, slick with dust and lore,
He tip-checked his flat-heel, he brushed his scripts once more;
With a flit of wing-sash, with a flick of lamp and lace,
He stepped into the velvet and met the creature face to face.

The beast made a scrabble-shrug, all bobbin, bob, and blink,
Her snout went slush for confetti, her eyes like stage-glue wink;
She chattered sash-snick, she hissed a cueful tune,
She tangled up the gobos and gnawed a travelling-boon.

"Stand steady!" cried the gaffer, "Hold thy cue and hush thy breath!"
Player-Jin did a sidestep, then a courteous pirouette of death;
He wrestled with a tumble-sash, he unknotted rope and seam,
Till Basklewick unspooled herself and fled the wings' half-dream.

Now curtains settle like soft-lids, the wings breathe velvet-sigh,
The propmice scuttle homeward and the flylines furl on high;
Keep careful, actors, of the shadows where the stage-wind hums and sings,
For under velvet edges dances all manner of Wingwurm things.

The milk-crumbs bremble, sing;

Avoid the scorchle’s angry speck,
Lest all your patience come.

poem:
The Creep

In gloam of hed and knotted lane the snickle-boughs droop low,
Where whisper-lichen tucks its head and night-crumbs silver slow;
From skirl of root and bramble-breath the creepsome came a-glide,
A lean, limed shadow, soft of tooth, with glassy, sideways eye.

"Mind the Creep!" the ancients croon'd, "it threads the seam of sound,
It slips between the pulse and thought and tills the timid ground;
It sips the courage from your boots, it skews the straight to bent,
It learns your sleep and paints your name in frost along the tent."

So Arden took his glim-blade bright, and cinched his cloak-snare tight,
He paced the quaver-flagged lane where murk and moonlight fight,
And there, among the boggled reeds, Vorleth-thing uncurled,
A rusted crown upon its naps, a whisper-broth that whirled.

He swung with snatch and snicker-swing till moon-sparks spat and flew,
The Creep it crooned a kelpish note and folded up like dew;
They flung the old brave-song aloud — a shout, a brazen ring —
Vorleth slid mute to ragged dusk, and silence took to cling.

Now hearths breathe brimmer in the lanes where once the brondles wept,
Yet when the dusk unbuttons slow, keep watch where shadows slept:
For slink it may, in velvet hush, some tiny, gnawing sweep,
And leave a last, long-lingering trace — the sly, small thing called Creep.

The Awl-Song

Beware the sting of sleethy Awl;
Wrap leather snug, set stout thy head,
Lest twirple-tips make seamlines maul.

Twas brintly noon on grimmish lea,
The awl-bird chirred its pin-pique cry;
With spangling eye and bristle-bee,
It pricked the hides and darted by.

"Beware the Awl!" the cobbler cried,
"With slithy point and glinting maw;
It skitter-slips where stitches hide,
And jinks the welt with jag and jaw."

So forth I went with hammer-hum,
My apron gnaved, my awl held tight;
I bore the bristle-blade of rum,
And followed flebbing beam of light.

It snicked! it sprung! — the hide gave way,
The twizzle-tack sang thin and clear;
I threaded dawn through leather-play,
And mended seams with flibber-gear.

The Awl did dance its whitter-dance,
It prinked the welt, it spooled the seam;
But steady hand and patient glance
Unmade its bite with stitch and dream.

Of patched-up maps and bootlace song;
Home-bound I strode, my heart so trull,
A vict'ry-skip, a thrumming gong.

Rejoice! ring bells! let bobbins flare;
The cobbles cheer, the lamps pour gold;
Awl-scare defeated by craft and care —
Return triumphant, stout and bold.

A fizzledrift of iron-high.

The Interferencewock

To bar the seep and sluice away.

A humble shield, a small fine art.

But glad-governed, kindly Umbrelloon;
It keeps the wet from brow and boot,
And tempts the sun to peep, compute.

The Fair-gleam Frabjous

All whirliglints and gizmo-grass, and banners glowed like steam;
The studentsnaps with minds alight, and tink-doll eyes aglow,
Set up their snickerboxes where the tinkletidings flow.

“O heed the prep,” so Mutterfain did warn with careful air,
“Beware the fritzled fumble, the snag, the blink, the snare;
Polish your schematics, brace your bolts, and check the power-snap,
For flibber-flaws will fluster you and fritz will bite and zap.”

Then forth the bold young Quimbly came, with solder, spool, and chart;
His project — a small wonder-thing: a steamered thought-sparkt heart.
He twizzled knobs and fluxed the coil, he snugged each screw and ring,
And hummed a tune of science-slate that made the fairbells sing.

Past fluttermotes and thermoblips and clever coggy-zens;
A snarkle-judge did frown and ask, “Explain your whir’ly scheme,”
Quimbly did grin and demo-flash his gleam-of-logic beam.

A hiccup-crack!—the photoflare! A sputter, then a spark—
The crowd held breath as gizmolite lit up the shadowed dark;
He steadied hand, he tweaked the wire, he coaxed the flume to purr,
And out the whimple-whizzer sang — a glist and glitter-gurr!

“O brave the labber, brave the mind!” the clubbers clap and cheer;
The ribbon-rim and trophy-tip did shim and shine so near.
They crowned the Quimbly champion of thought and fiddled fay,

Past lamp-posts swaying glim and gloam, beneath the moon’s mild light;
“Remember this,” did Quimbly say to friends both new and old:
“Prepare, be curious, be brave—let wonder lead your bold.”

The science-heart beats brilly yet — hooray! the Fair-gleam’s born.

The Jammerwock

The Monte-Carlo Mirlark

And lanterns hum and hop,
The casin’ beasts in velvet show
Do bingle, blink and flop.

And gird thy purse with thread;

That glint on gamblor’s bed.

And map thy luck with care;
The sprocket-spinners whirl the land
Where croupy-voices snare.

The blorble-men in tweed appear
And wink at silver's weight.

To play their humming suite.

And struck a spry-sweet ace.

poem:
The Cartodrake

Twas on a vellum-night, with the compass-gleam low,
And the fold-snick folk tiptipt near the seam,
Came the rustle of routes and the hush of the tow,
Where the ink-rills ran quick in a moonlit stream.
Gridle-groan mountains muttered their mapbound tale,
And the legend-gleams winked on the margin pale.

"Mind the Cartodrake!" cried a cartouche-child, bold,
"With its crease-claw teeth and its hush-skein mane;
It devours blank spaces, eats lost pins of old,
And curls up the roads into twist-crumbline chains."
From the northlurch ridge to the bay of pale ink,
It slithered the latitudes — sly as you'd think.

Sir Mapkin took compass, with thumb at the fold,
His needle a-spark and his heart like a drum;
He traced the inkle-path where the rumor ran cold,
Through the waywry woods where the soft shadows hum.
The Cartodrake hissed, 'neath a contour of grey,
Its tail a torn legend, its eye a blue bay.

Sir Mapkin, with rubric, unrolled the bright seam,
He sang out a route-song, a shirred paper hymn;
The Cartodrake flared, then it trembled and deemed
The folds too precise for its whimsy and grim.
With a snort and a flump it uncoiled and broke,
Leaving a clasp of a compass, a pin, and a spoke.

Now maps munch no more on the travellers' trusts,
And the margins lie quiet where wanderers roam;
If you spy a blank glint in the ink-forest dust,
Lay down a small sign and hum wayward home.
For the Cartodrake sleeps where the crease-lines are snug,
And the map-smiles glow soft with a fold-warmed snug.

With silvered smiles and pockets brim;

The Canticle of the Musicroom

In glimmergloom the music-room did sigh,
with timbrelumps and whiffling-keys awry;
the moth-bellows hummed a low glissawisp,
and plangent chandlers swung their silverlisp.

Along the parquet crept a whisper-tongue,
where clankeroot and foam-note trilled along;
a fiddler's ghost made bracket-waves to swoon,
and candle-strings went frabbling to the moon.

Then from the organ's shadow, sly and long,
came Cimbalfang, with snare-eyes keen and strong;
his lute-ribbed flank a velvet-bronze did gleam,
he sashayed in on mothsong and daydream.

"O hush!" quoth I, with rosined palm and bow,
"unhand that timp of dark, you pluckly woe!"
He sniffed a chord—half purr, half ping, half roar—
and stomped the hearth with thunder-heel galore.

I drew my rosin-sabre, tuned to bright,
and struck a scale that split the gloaming's night;
whimbletones spilled like starlight on a pond,
and Cimbalfang's fierce countenance grew fond.

He twined a croon of brazen, bubbled cheer,
and beat his tail in syncopated gear;
the chandlers chinked, the moth-bellows did clap,
the music-room became a luminous lap.

So now, when dusk corrustles down the stair,
you'll hear the pluck of paws and pensive air;
the Cimbalfang presides with velvet hum,
and timbres dream where once the silence drum.

poem:
The Déjà-Drake

'Twas glimbling hour, and swithey streets
did hum with twicey, tickled beats;
All borogroves blinked doubly-blind
and mirror-moss looped round the mind.

Beware the Déjà-Drake, my friend!
Its echo-breath will twist and bend;
Beware its mimic, murmur-eye,
that leads you where you've been — and fly.

Take up your steady glim-lamp, hold
your heart with quiet, not too bold;
Tie tight your thought with twine of care,
for flash-back fog will snare you there.

He stepped — the cobbles sang once more,
the lamplight traced a ghostly floor;
The market's bell sang twice the tune,
and shadow-steps came up too soon.

"Repeat," it hissed in twicey-speech,
a slur of memory within reach;
He braced his knees, he breathed with chew,
and met the mirror-thing anew.

He did not stab — he simply smiled,
and bowed to that old twicey child;
Then turned his face to forward sun,
and danced the loop till loop was done.

O frabjoy! O frizzing day!
Calloosh! Callay! The echoes play!
With jiggle-joy and jubilee,
he brought the borrowed light back free.

So if that lurching twice-song calls,
prepare your lamp, and mend your walls;
Grip gently, hum a steady tune,
and meet the twice with merry swoon.

Return then home with laugh and plume —
the Déjà-Drake becomes a plume;
Huzzle-hail, the mind's made new:
rejoice, O friend, in déjà vu!

The Creep of Crimblemere

And hummed a rueful rhymed salute.

The moon clapped hands, the stars drew near,
And Crimblemere danced on its feets.

For victors bring the morning's peep
And feast on frabjous pie and sky.

And Waywallow watches, pleased, from hedgeride.

Unplug the beast, let spindle cool, don gloves of rubbered blue;
Keep steady light, a tweezer fine, and patience strong and true.

He slid his hand through pulley fog, with whimblegraft and ploom,
The spindles clicked with spindleclack, the fuser sighed and gloom.
The jam did crumple, greeble-snap, a wrangle, snarl, and tug;
He spoke no word but hummed a tune, and pried the stubborn plug.

Out slithered drum and wrinkled sheet, in twine of ink and jam,
A flutter, plop, a jubiliump — the printer gave a dam.
He smoothed each page with trindle-finger, brushed the toner free,
And set the tray with jaunty snap — oh, what a sight to see!

He came back in, a merry march, the corridors to greet,
With crisp, warm prints held high aloft — a clattering, bold treat.
The office laughed, the copier sang, a whirliglee unfurled,
For one brave soul had beaten back the Jamblot's shabby world.

So heed the warning, keep your tools, and learn the quiet art:
Prepare — unplug, cool, and plan — be calm, and don't be tart.
Then go and meet the jam with care; return with triumph's cheer —
For sheets will sing and bosses grin when you have saved the year.

poem:
Echoquell

In the thrummock dusk, when the pavements hum twice,
A twinegloom shivers beneath the lamplight's lace,
And faces you barely recall come back like a spice,
Stirring old laugh-motes in the pocket of place.

Past the curbing of hours a recurboon slides,
Soft as a murmur and clipped as a bell,
It leaves a small ache where the new memory hides,
A mirror-spark snagged in the knuckle of hell.

Then Glimmerwurm wanders the hush of the lane,
His whiskers are echoes, his footsteps are clues;
He noses the corner where time loops the same,
Wagging a tail full of dusk-colored news.

You clutch at the moment that flowers in reverse,
A bloom of déjà spun, both uncanny and true;
The world hums a stanza of old, then a verse,
And you sip at the sip you supposed you once knew.

So follow the echoquell down to the last knot,
Let the recurloon spin you like thread back to view;
There is comfort and fright in the twice-taken spot —
When the flickershade welcomes you, welcome it too.

poem:
Ballad of the Muzzleroom

Hark, take heed, and brace thy ear, O child of cord and plume,
Beware the Bellow-Bass that booms within the Muzzleroom;
Snare not the snigger-squawk that springs from plinkled, pronged perfume,
But grip thy bow, and set thy breath, and light thy tuning-lume.

The lamp was glimmed, the floorboards hummed with frumple-fingered cheer,
The harpsnakes twined their gliss'ry lines, the clackled cymbals near;
A snorflute sighed its wobbled notes, the piano plinked a sneer,
While little plimpets danced their dots and jumbled jams did steer.

I took my fiddle, frobbed my pick, and gave a striggle-snap,
A trumple-tongue of trumpet-tongue replied—a glistering clap;
The Snaggle-score, that tangle-god, coiled tight in midnight wrap,
But steady-thought and steady-hand unknotted every trap.

"Beware!" cried I, "the wobbly-wonk, the thrum of hollow doom,"
"Beware the floor that gobbles time, the wobble-wash of gloom!"
So tuned I thrice the silver string, and struck the glowing broom,
And notes like flittering featherfish dispelled that slouch of gloom.

With ribble-roll and flutter-fleck the Muzzleroom then cleared,
The Bellow-Bass fell meek and small, its grumble barely heard;
The snapped-up scores lay calm and clean, the tangled tunes endeared,
And every plimblenote that stayed sang sweet, not something blurred.

Homeward I trod with brassy bloom and lilt upon my bloom,
Come to my arms, ye merry songs, return from music-room;
We feasted on the echo-bright, with clink and choral boom,
All beamish-beat and plinky-sweet—our hearts in hoom and plume.

prompt: Write a poem about layover bay in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
Layover Bay

When dusk-fog draped the quays of Layover Bay,
and ferrylights blinked like slow-fireflies,
the suitcases snuffled in linen-snooze,
and skycars hummed low in the hush of sighs.
Soft dribble-waves lapped the quayblot sand;
all was baybright and half-asleep.

“Mark well,” said the portmonger, “in tide-gleam hush,
the Skitterbrush folds and the floomb-tides play —
for there skulks the Snerglewump by the whale-rail arch,
with glint-snout wet and murk-eye gray.”
He clicked his knuckle-keys and spat a twickled rue:
“Mind your maps and your heart.”

I donned my hushlance and my satchel of crumbs,
with a snap-scarf tight and a nerble-light low,
and stepped where the layover shadows curl —
past luggage-moss and the last snack-glow.
The quay-boards creaked a jing-jang song,
and the air went skreeble-still.

Then out from the kelp-bleths and the slooming spray
swept Snerglewump, all whisker and wheel,
his back a barnacle of odd-glass gleams,
his talons clamped on a lost travel-steel.
He bellowed a snorble, he flailed a wing,
he tramped the layover dark.

I lunged with my hushlance, with a zip and a zawn,
and the floom-spark flittered, and tinsel-leaves flew,
the Snerglewump toppled with a gurgle-sigh,
and the bayfolk cheered in a mingled coo.
I hefted his whisker for keepsake’s sake
and trod back to bright concourse.

Now when layovers lengthen and tide-thoughts stray,
and travelers yawn at the gate-lit fray,
they whisper of Snerglewump’s foamy pass,
and smile at the hushlance’s glow of day.
Layover Bay sleeps with its luggage snug;
but beware the sly tide-song.

poem:
The Conferroom-Bewitch

Twas glim and glum in the clatter-room,
When snick-slate lights did blink,
And swivel-chairs in slithered gloom
Around the roundtable slink.
The mungled screen with shimmer-splay
Did glub and ghost in view,
While coffee-fogs and post-it-spray
Pufted the morning through.

"Beware the PowerPoint," quiver-cry,
"Mind mute and maddening ping!
Clamp your agendas, trim your sigh —
Let prep be everything.
Tie your slides with clip-and-tack,
Arm your notes with grin,
Lest agenda-creeps the hour attack
And swelch your patience thin."

Then forth strode Bold Sir Lead, all bram,
With pointer-brace in hand;
He faced the Slide-Snitch, the Clock-Ghost's dram,
And quelled the Quibble-band.
He jabber-juggled terms and charts,
And flumm'd the jargon-swarm;
He nodded firm, won stubborn hearts,
And soothed the spreadsheet-storm.

They brainstormed bright with dingled-thoughts,
They scribbled whimsy-ware;
They pivot-popped like springing knots
And shared the glory-fair.
At last the minute-paper came,
Signed neat with scribble-spark;
They cheered the wins, they named no blame,
Their triumph lit the dark.

Home trudged the team, all blithesome-beamed,
Their badges jingled free;
He brought the minutes, kromp and gleamed,
And sang the follow-up decree.
So prep your quills and guard your tone,
Brace swivel, screen, and mind;
Then meet, then conquer, then come home,
With hurrah left behind.

The Creep of Grindle-Glen

Beware the Creep that creeps by cove;

Lest slinklesnatch thy shadow fade.

Its toes go tarr and tipsy-steer.

Nor let its whisper snag your heel."

A wobble-wraith with wobble-wond.

Stand brave, tiptoe, or boldly leap —
And home come dancing when you beat the Creep.

The Fogwreath Ballad

Hush, gird thy sash and snap thy cloak, my friend,  
Hear the fogwhistle trilling from the damp;  
Tuck your lamp and learn the twil-scheme to bend,  
For dawn is slithy with the mornfog's vamp.

Down the drowse-path, through the gloamish swath we go,

And the froomy vapors curl and cramp.

Mind the snicket-snakes of steam that loop and lean,  
Do not chase the murk with a brag or cramp;  
Grip thy fogstaff, steady, in the muddle between,  
Lest the whimble of wonder tie thy lamp.

We met the ghastle-graze and the blinker-beast,  
Gave a skree and a skitter, then a nimble stamp;  
With a clack and a chuck we outwrithed the feast,  
And the vapors broke like a silvered ramp.

Home we hymn with jaunt-joy, our pockets bright with dew,  
Hoorloo! Hoorra! Let the hearthers clap and camp;  
Bring the mornfog's story—strange, soft, and new—  
And crown the dawn with a jubilant framp.

The Thrum of the Third Rail

In gloam-dim blink of trackside eve,
when tinsel-fogs go snuff and weave,
the third-rail hum begins to comb
the platform's bones with low chrome-thrum.

It purrs in frimble, skirrlick tones,
a lullaby of iron-bones,
a heavy whisper, humblethrum,
that makes the lamp-flowers quiver-thrum.

Beware the glint of singe-slick sparks,
the sizzled lace at midnight marks;
for Quilver the Sparkwurm coils and slips
along the rail with glim-gleam lips.

He feeds on brench of current-sheen,
and leaves a fret of fizz between;
then slinks beneath the arc and steam,
a sparrow-fang of neon-gleam.

So hush, ye feet, and hush, ye breath,
let not your shadow cross his path;
the third-rail thrubble keeps its law,
a bright dark thing with humming maw.

In drimsy hush and rumble-glade,
the trackbirds fold their copper-made;
and if you catch that low-beat drum,
remember — listen, don't become.

The Shutterwight

Hark! Mind the bright that sneaks and slips,
O keeper of the filmy flips;
Wind snug the spool, cock snap and screw —
Let no sun-sneak slurp the dew.

Load soft the cannister, click the glass,
Twist the sprocket, let spool pass;
Thumb the aperture, grimble the light,
Prepare thy lens for gloam and bite.

Through murk and mirk the snapbeasts glide,
Flashflit and glim in sprockle-ride;
Shutterwump! — a staccato cry,
Grain-gleams dance, the shadows fly.

Spin the rewind, hush the hiss,
Fold the negatives, tender and crisp;
Darkle-room with fixer-mist,
Bathe each frame in silver-kiss.

Then home he trots, with prints aglow,
A clatter of cheer, a clickety-show;
"Lo the frames!" the folk all sing —
Snick and snatch, the jubilants ring.

Thus heed the warn, take care, prepare —
Wield well thy filmy, fragile care;
For those who brave the shutter's night
Return with treasures — bright delight.

The Flickerfang

In the darkroom of the tulgy wood,
The Flickerfang clicks and snaps;
Its lensglimmer bright, a mimsy sight,
As the filmwhirl unwraps.

Beware the shutterfraps that snap,
The aperture opening wide;
The Focus-sprite dances in light,
While moments inside abide.

Oh, camera bold with viewfinder keen,
You capture time with beamish hand;
Through chemicals and light between,
You make the moment stand.

The Flickerfang with flash so bright,
Does whirr and click with glee;
It snaps the day and freezes night,
For all eternity.

He turned the dial with uffish might,
And pressed the button down;
The Flickerfang did work aright,
And earned its darkroom crown.

poem:
The Awl's Adventure

Gimbletide in the punctulate wood,
Where twistum vines and spinnetts grew,
The holify groves with awl-sharp points,
All glistening with morning dew.

A Vorpal Awl, so keen and bright,
Was carried by a lad so bold,
Through Grumbledeep and Puncturepass,
A story waiting to unfold.

The dreaded Awlwing, fierce and fast,
With piercing beak and talons keen,
Lurked in the shadows of the Murkwood,
A sight never before seen.

The lad approached with caution vast,
His silver awl held at the ready,
He crept and tiptoed through the brush,
His movements slow and steady.

Suddenly, with whiffling sound,
The Awlwing burst from tangled vines,
Its eyes like flames, its beak so sharp,
The most terrifying of signs!

One stab! Two stab! The awl went true!
Through scale and feather, deep and fast,
The Awlwing gave a final cry,
A mighty triumph at the last.

The lad returned with awl in hand,

The Flimflam Camera's Frantic Froll

The Flimflam camera's power is strong and new.

poem:
Underpass Murmurlurk

Under the overroad it gloamed; the dribble-drabs went plink,
The spraypaint sigils glimmered wet; the tunnel kept its think;
A tramble-wind went scroodle-sigh through girders ribbed and cold,
And echo-bells looped back on back, a silver-snarl unrolled.

My granny spoke in clattercant: “Mind Murmurlurk’s old moan;
It eats your shout and answers twice, but never walks alone.
It skulks in sumpershadow, child, where puddle-stars are laid—”
I tipped my cap and shouldered up my hushhook and my blade.

I donned a mufflemantle tight, soft socks of squeezy tread,
A jitter-jar for lightning noise, a no-echoing head;
Through graffitine and dripstone blur the bellow-arches sighed,
And far along the rumblestair a flitter-gnarl replied.

Then out it swarfed—Murmurlurk!—its lantern-larynx glowed,
With knuckle-knots of echo-gnash along its jiggled jaw;
It gulped my little coughs and grew, revolved them as it strode,
And guggle-sang my guggle twice, loud-larger than the law.

I flung my jitter-jar ajar and rattled clink and clack,
The tunnel bloomed with clatter-blooms; it shuddered, cronked, and back;
The hushhook hooked its hollowness—I reeled the hollow in—
It buckechoked and quaver-cried, a reverb-ruffled din.

We dancetamped till the rustflakes snowed; the curb-kept beetles fled,
The Murmurlurk unlipped my name, then slackened like a thread;
I let the quiet slowly knit where ruckus had been torn,
And every drip-drop found its place upon the undermorn.

Now under overroad it gloams; the driplets dreel and blink,
The lamp-gnats wheel in amber mist; the tunnel keeps its think;
I whisper so the whisper stays, not roused to wildest work—
For loudness breeds its lurk again, that murmy Murmurlurk.

Ballad of the Morning Mizzle

Dawn drimbles down the cobble-close,
Soft glimmerwisps uncurled;
The rooftops don their sloomy coats,
A mufflet of the world.

"Pack glim and buttoned boot;

A fluffle-thing, the Mornybog,

"Ho, hush you, kindly cloudle-kin,"

We waltzed the lanes in slooshy steps,

Past drumble-gates and snoozy sheds,
We foggleglid a mile.

Then, back again to Kettle Lane,
I burst in bright with cheer;
Gran poured the kettle's vict'ry song,
"Huzzah for finding, dear!"

So when the dawn goes murmurmurk,

Be booted, lit, and merry-brave—
The fuzzle-fog leads home.

poem:
Ballad of the Eversame Loopwurm

At gloaming-turn the snindle groves
went quirl and whorl through dew;
The path had twice-remembered coves—
I swore I'd walked it too.

My gran did say, “Mind Loopwurm’s grin,
that echomaw of yore;
It eats the ‘once’ and coils the ‘when’
till now becomes before.”

I hefted up my Recurver blade,
its edge a circling gleam;
It felt as if my fingers made
the grip inside a dream.

Out from the thrum of hushful air
the Loopwurm loomed anew—
a helix hide, a spiral stare,
an againward, misty hue.

It hissed, “Again,” with loopish breath;
the wind went round in rings;
We danced the duel we’d danced at death,
recalling unborn things.

I struck; it bent the moment back,
my cut returned to me;
I curved my slash against its track
and split the symmetry.

The world said click; the shadows sighed;
a twindle-clock chimed two;
I knew that I had surely died—
or lived the scene askew.

I raised the Recurver up once more—
or was it thrice or twice?—
and nicked the knot of evermore,
the center of its splice.

The Loopwurm shrank to thimble-time
and trembled, thin and blue;
It blinked and birthed the selfsame rhyme,
then vanished like a clue.

And all the snindle groves went still,
the dew unwhorled its tune;
Yet Echo-Lane ran up the hill
as if it knew me soon.

At gloaming-turn the snindle groves
went quirl and whorl through dew;
The path had twice-remembered coves—
Had I not walked it too?

Ballad of the Desirepath

The Agendagon of Room 3B

the glarefluorescents bloom;

around the carpet-gloom.

beneath the ventwind's drone;

its jargonosis lost its joint,

The Clatterlark of the Music Room

went tickle-tack in gloom;

within the music room.

the snickle-snare, the drum!
Beware the Hushhound’s velvet wild,
and mind the whistling hum!"

a star-drawn paper stave;
He tiptoed into tambourland
where echo-chimes behave.

the Clatterlark drew near,
with clitter-clatter rattlance
that prinkled up the ear.

Click-clack! went keys and kettleskin;
he spun a bright refrain;
He wove a swash of fiddlin'
and sealed the snare in strain.

tamed boomers to a purr;
The Clatterlark unflapped its fright
and dwindled: whirr-whirr-whirr.

he trod with gleeful bloom;

he cried into the room.

and calm their crankled tune?"

No Clatterlark, no Hushhound roams

In the Folded Hours
Skritch was the vellum; the rhumbish roads
Went curl and crook through latitune;
The meridreams in longimodes
Did hummle by the compass-moon.

The scale-toothed, legend-lurking brute!
Its paperwings go flit-and-keen,
Its inky maw makes marsh of route!"

His chartshield of the grid-and-glaze;
He cinched a rosewind balustrade
And stepped into the contour maze.

Through eastingwood and northingmere,
Past contourcrests and index-stone,
The vellumvale was crisp with fear;
The mapling groves were crease-and-groan.

While he was musing at rhumbelake,
The Cartogriff, all crinkle-sheen,
Came scrummeling down the margin-flake,
Eyes azimutch and legend-green.

Tick-tack! and through the vellum air
The compass-blade went clitter-clat!

He nicked its fold and flattened that.

He spoke a counter-placery,
And stitched the route together then.

"O hurrahful morn!" the elders sang,
"You’ve charmed the map’s misguiding riff!
No more our paths go skurl and tang,
All thanks to you—and Cartogriff."

Skritch went the vellum; the rhumbish lanes
Lay smooth and true by compass-light;
The meridreams in longimains
Made homely hums through folded night.

The Lingerling of Layover Bay

went wheeling spray and sway;
the trolleycrabs went scritch and scrall
about old Layover Bay.

the Glumlag’s grumly bray;
buckle thy beeps and boarding slips,
and chart a nimble way.

avoid their drowsy lay;
take up thy timeloom pocket-knife
and keep thy wits in play.”

his crispish nibble-tray,
and tiptoed past the gatewood planks
that rimmed the lapping bay;

When from the fog, with yawnmouth wide,
there swelled (oh, bleak buffet!)
the Lingerling, the Yawny-bogg,
that chews the hours away.

Its ticket-stripling tentacles
went flaffle-snap and flay;
its carry-on of midnight moans
dead-quieted the day.

He drew his timeloom blade and swung,
a clocket-ticking ray;
it snippet-snapped—skrick-scrack it sang—
and trimmed the gloom to gay.

Then stillness popped like bubblewrap,
the lagglegulls made spray;
the Lingerling rolled back to dream,
unhinged and set at bay.

Return, my sprightly jay—”
He came guluffing up the quay
to cheers along the quay.

and snicked its nips away!”
They clinked the cups of lemon-fizz
beside bright Layover Bay.

And laytime hummed: the trolleycrabs
went scritch and scrall and sway;
the world, unglummed, went click-o-clock
around sweet Layover Bay.

Ballad of the Roulettiwump of Monte Carlo

It was twillick on the Rivierine; the gildersheen did flow,
The yachts went yebb and yabberly along the azurial bow,
The croupieroons with click-clack smiles made meteors of the wheel,
And bellish chips went chinkle-chank beneath the marbled feel.

"Take heed," quoth Auntie Grimaldine, "the Roulettiwump doth prowl,
The Bankerbarb with ledgered grin, the Slotling’s sugar howl;
Grip tight your luckbright common-sense, keep pockets clasped and keen,
And shun the martingale-mirth that gulps the giltigrin."

I buckled on my chancelet blade and donned my bravado,
I stuffed my purse with crispish dreams and coins of clinkcado;
I mapped a million maybe-paths, by pebble, point, and star,
And whispered to my beating odds, "Monte! Monte! Car!"

Through Corniche curves and grotto-glints I strode the moonlit rim,
When out there swung a glitter-thing, all whirligogne and grim;
Its eyes were double-zero green, its grin was houseward wide,
It purred, "Come play the chancele-dance," and twinkled, "Place your pride."

I spun my blade with tlick and tlack, I sampled left and right,
I let the dicesim cascade to scout the hidden bite;
The Roulettiwump went whirr and whump, its marbles sang ker-ching,
I timed the tide of ficklefate and leapt within the ring.

A cut! a cut! the gilty gut of odds was split in two,
The zero eyes went pop and pale; the wheel unhinged its hue;
The Bankerbarb unbristled, and the Slotling spun to sleep,
The croupieroon bowed thrice and sighed, "Your wagers yours to keep."

Back up the stairs of marble-lilt I tripped with jingling cheer,
My purse went ping, my heart went pong, the Riviera drew near;
"Rejoice!" cried Grimaldine, "you brave and budget-bolstered star!
Hug upon hug! Hooray and ha!" We danced, "Monte! Monte! Car!"

poem:
The Gloomalurk and the Creep

By blinkish eve the gutters gleam,
and creep goes siddle-slow;
It threadles thin through latch and seam,
a hushfur flibber-flow.
The chimneys murk, the wainscots weep,
and stair-treads dreel and shrink—
For creep, that grimsip, drip by drip,
comes slinkering to the brink.

Who hears its skreel? Not brass nor bell—
it muffles gudgered chime;
It steals your inch and calls it well,
it nibbles nick by time.
It gnaws the day to drindle dusk,
it nudges No to Maybe;
It oils the locks with glim and musk
till stout hearts turn to wavery.

The Gloomalurk goes gloam-a-low,
a night-sap, sleek and sere;
With mirlish maw and slubber toe,
it pats the creeping near.
It pets the creep, it feeds it crumbs,
it hums a whifflish lilt—
And walls grow furred with hushful sums
of dust and dun and silt.

I fetched my sunspike, frail but keen,
a candle-gnit of gold;
I breathed a brash and brisky sheen
against the hush and cold.
Through nibblefog and snerkled fear
I strode with jitter-jack,
To meet the Lurk where lean stairs leer—
with flamelit, flitter-crack.

In snudget thought I felt it creep,
it trouched along my sleeve;
A little loss, a lazy seep—
and how was I to leave?
The bannisters grew fur and fuzz,
the corners full of blink;
The Gloomalurk made cozy buzz
and urged me not to think.

Then rang my tinny sunspike bright,
it pintled up the stair;
The creep went scrittle from the light,
the Lurk unspooled to air.
I fluster-swept the drindle gloom,
I bellied out the blips;
By broom of dawn and window-bloom
I shooed the siddle creeps.

Now keep your thresholds trim and trim,
your lamplight plucky-clear;
Let drindle doubts grow lean and slim,
and mind what sidles near.
For creep is never bang or boom
but lint and little work;
It wins by whisper, gloom by gloom—
and so does Gloomalurk.

poem:
The Awlward Ballad

By lamplight spun the leathern scraps,
The bench went knick and knurl;
The thrumble-dust on cobbler’s caps
Went skitter-scrit and whirl.

“Put on thy thimble, wax thy thread,
And mind thy nimble paw;
Beware the snaggle-scrim,” he said,
“And keep from prickle-thraw.”

He took his awl—round, awl-round bright,
With beechen grip and shine;
A pick of prick, a point of light,
A punctil prickle-spine.

Through hide and hidey-stitchel fields
He poked with pokesome grace;
The scuffle-burrs and bramble-shields
All crimped before his pace.

Out sprang the Snip-Snarl from the welt,
Its teeth all stitch and straw;
It hissed, it snagged; the cobbler felt
A quiver in his claw.

One awlward thrust—no cut nor slash—
But dink! a dimpled hole;
He twirled and twizzled, thrum and dash,
And laced the leather whole.

The seam ran true through loop and loop,
Like brooklets through a shaw;

The Third-Rail Voltivex

The Jammertangle

And jitter-jived bizarre.

"O gleesome day! Hoo-lay! Hoo-rise!"

The ringled waves ran clean and clear;
Soft minglespun, yet tuned as one—
No snarl, no splotch of smear.

poem:
The Umbrellicle and the Umbregoon

In drindle dusk the puddles plashed; the plitterfain was loud,
And quorlish winds went splosherly through dripplestarry cloud;
The cobbles slick with glumbrel-glaze, the lamplight skeined with rain,
While spokelings dreamed in canvas-fold and dozed their clacky brain.

“Keep close your Umbrellicle,” whispered Auntie Wrain,
“It blooms a dusk-defender in the dropplecrowding plain;
For out there prowls Umbregoon, a shade-scarf–snapping brute,
Who gulps the glow from windowpanes and gnaws the puddle’s loot.”

I took my brave umbrella then, its twistifoldy stem,
Its ferrulefoot went tap-a-tip along the gutter’s hem;
I pressed the bloom-spring—hup! it fluffed, a round and ribby star,
A patterplume above my head, a hush against the spar.

Through drippy lanes and sloshsome lanes, I strode with brolly bright,
It murmured plip and pluppleplap, it held a pocketed light;
Then out from under eaves a-skirr, with glare-devouring eyes,
The Umbregoon in draggled shawls came glumping from the skies.

It hissed in dampish trundle-tongue, “I favor shade for stew;
I’ll crumple up your spokeling nest and thieve its cozy blue!”
I set my Umbrellicle to whirl, a whirliwhap so spry,
The ribs went clack-o-clack and sang a shelterbattle cry.

We grappled in the splashsome fog—a twizzle, twack, and turn;
Its teeth made nips at gossamer, my knuckles nipped at fern;
I pendulumed the twistifold; the ferrule gave a thud,
And puddles leapt like kettles set to giggle out their suds.

Then sudden as a thunder-smirk it tumbled, gloom askew,
My canvas-bloom unwrinkled it, and shook the storm in two;
The Umbregoon went skitter-back, all snuffed of saucy spite,
And skulked into the drainmouth’s throat to chew the leftover night.

The lanes unblurred; the lamplight purred; the plitterfain grew mild,
I folded up my brolly-heart, a tulip tame and tiled;
And home I went through glimmer-town with ferrule tapping true—
O bless the dear Umbrellicle that keeps the world from dew.

Shuttergryx in Silverdream

Umbrellikin and the Dripdraggle

The eaves drip slurpy blues.

My Umbrellikin keeps off the haze
